titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Photographs of Asian Americans
titlestmt.author: by Matthew Daniel Mason

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 07:23

did.unittitle: Photographs of Asian Americans.

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Photographs of Asian Americans created by Asian American photographers and others, chiefly in California, circa 1930-1982.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired from various sources. For more information see notes associated with each photograph.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
This collection has no permanent box or folder designations for items within it, so patrons should note the photographer and image description when requesting materials

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Photographs of Asian Americans is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Photographs of Asian Americans. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection serves as a means for bringing together photographic materials acquired singularly and in small groups. Occasionally, a critical mass of photographs by a particular photographer or studio accrues within the collection and becomes the basis for a seperate collection documenting that individual or studio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs of Asian Americans created by Asian American photographers and others, chiefly in California, circa 1930-1982.

Portraiture in the collection includes wedding portraits and graduation portraits, as well as studio portraits of families and individuals. Identified sites of images include a group in front of the Soto Zen Mission of the Sokoji Buddhist Church in San Francisco, California, and a group portrait of attendees of the Western Federation of Buddhist Sunday School Teachers League Conference in front of the Lodi Buddhist Church in Lodi, California, in January 1957.

Photographers represented in the collection include Eschol Manning Hammond, Paul Henry Hammond, Miyowa (George) Hishida, Sadaichi Imada, Morinosuke (Jack) Kamikihara, Charles Fred Kohler, and Richard S. Yoshikawa.

Photographic studios represented in the collection include Barboni Studio, George Studio , Hammond Studio, Imada Studio, Kami Studio, Salon Studio, Sandino Studio, Tru-Lite Studio, Wee Picture Studio, and Yoshikawa Studio.

Image descriptions of the photographic prints are derived from inscriptions on the verso and recto of the item and from image analysis by the archivist. Descriptions usually include information about the working locations of the photographer or studio, and occasionally physical characteristics of items, such as image numbers applied by the photographers or inscriptions by previous owners, as well as contextual information about the images.
Each folder contains a single photographic print.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: I. Photographs, circa 1930-circa 1965. II. Oversize Photographs, circa 1930-1982.

did.unittitle: Photographs

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by the surname of the photographer or the corporate name of the studio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of vintage photographic prints with dimensions less than 22 x 29 cm (8.7 x 11.4 in.). Photographic materials with dimensions larger than 22 x 29 cm (8.7 x 11.4 in.) are located in the Oversize Photographs series.

did.unittitle: Barboni Studio

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Barboni Studio was a photography studio in Oakland and San Francisco, California

acqinfo.p: Purchased from Bolerium Books on the Arthur Corbitt Hoskins Memorial Fund, 2011

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Photography studio of Japanese American photographer Miyowa (George) Hishida (1896-1992) in Fresno, California

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Kamikihara, Morinosuke (Jack)
Kohler, Charles Fred

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Charles Fred Kohler (1874-1957) operated a photography studio in Los Angeles, California

did.unittitle: Studio portrait of two Asian American men, identified as Liang Xin Fang and his father

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographic print housed in a cardboard mat folder with an ink stamp identifying the photographer on the recto interior of the folder
Ink inscription in Chinese on the interior of the mat folder, "Fang, Liang Xin, and his father, for Zhou, Cheng Fang, 1943"

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Bolerium Books on the Arthur Corbitt Hoskins Memorial Fund, 2011

Tru-Lite Studio

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Photography studio located at 862 Clay Street, San Francisco, California

did.unittitle: Informal group portrait of eleven couples of Asian American men and women
Studio portrait of a Chinese American woman wearing a mortar board and gown, identified as Mary Mae Cheong

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographic print housed in a cardboard mat folder with an indistinct ink stamp identifying the studio, possibly Nu-Art Studio, on the recto interior of the folder, as well as an inscription in ink to Mrs. Lee from Cheong.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Mary Mae Cheong (born circa 1921) graduate from Lowell High School in San Francisco in 1939 and from the University of California at Berkeley in 1944

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Bolerium Books on the Arthur Corbitt Hoskins Memorial Fund, 2011

did.unittitle: Interior group portrait of nine Asian American men and an Asian American woman posed standing behind a casket, probably in a funeral parlor; one man wears regalia that designates him as a Buddhist clergyman

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Bolerium Books on the Arthur Corbitt Hoskins Memorial Fund, 2011

did.unittitle: Informal interior portrait of two Japanese American men; they wear hats that identify their membership in Townsend Harris Post No. 438 of the American Legion in San Francisco, California

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Bolerium Books on the Arthur Corbitt Hoskins Memorial Fund, 2011
